text: I'm impatiently waiting to get my hands on a Switch to play this (I know the Wii U version is completely OK, but it's not like I don't already have tons of games to play), and with such a historically high reception, I'm beyond excited. I went to a friend's house last week and he showed a couple parts and the size of the world, how dense it is and the number of things you can do is mind boggling. He also showed me a few minutes of the Hyrule Castle as he was about to go fight Ganon and hearing this theme was amazing. Honestly, this raises a new bar for Open World games and I wonder how other developers will react to prevent their own games in the genre from feeling bland. I look forward to playing it and give it my full thoughts here afterwards.
author: SupraDarky

text: I believe everyone who plays Breath of the Wild will have complaints (both minor and major ones), but most of them arises from the way you play it. BotW is not only completely non-linear, but it also gives the player a lot of freedom in their own play style. I know a lot of people who played it, and everyone played it in different ways. One did a lot of sidequests, one rushed directly to dungeons, one did not use potions and food so that battles got harder, etc. I feel like BotW will revolutionize the open world genre. Its level design is stellar to say the least, far beyond most games. If you play it, have fun! It really is a good game.
author: Eirian Odalis

text: Speaking of the overworld: Monoltih Soft (known for Xenoblade) helped Nintendo with BotW. Which means that every piece of the overworld is made by hand, and not generated biomes like many other open world games (like Skyrim). The attention to details is overwhelming.
author: Eirian Odalis

text: I'm also waiting on buying a switch. I may pick one up this summer of course with this game. I'm trying not to look at gameplay or watch reviews of this game. Being a long time Zelda fan, I'm sure it's amazing.

text: The game is so epic its almost overwhelming. I do recommend it though. Agree this theme makes challenging the ruined castle feel truly epic.
author: ragnaroktomorrow

text:
I got it for the Wii U, good times. I'd just get it for the Wii U if you have one, but yeah it's your call if you really feel like you have to wait. I wouldn't even consider getting a Switch until Christmas. I wound up actually loving the WIi U after all when I randomly bought it one summer sale.  There just isn't a lot on the Switch at all now. 

I don't really get that soft launch entirely though I'd like to see the Switch do well as I feel bad for the Wii U in some aspects. Nintendo gimped themselves relying too much on the tablet gimmick, but I still like the Wii U a lot anyways (never owning a Wii helps my case for it too).
author: notyoursavior78

text: I do not think you need to not own a Wii to love your Wii U. It has a lot of amazing games. Like Wonderful 101, Yoshi's Wooly World, Xenoblade X, Zelda BotW, Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze, etc.
author: Eirian Odalis

text: Even though BotW lived up to its hype for many people, there are always those for which it did not. If so, the hype is most probably its downfall. BotW is a great game, but everyone will find both objective and subjective flaws in it.

text: This song is made 1000 times more impactful if you hear it for the first time by going straight to the castle from the plateau. The music only adds to that feeling of being over your head.

author: The Destati

text: I disagree Destati. BotW shares many aspects of the Zelda series (excellent world building, weird npcs, etc.), and it shares more aspects with the NES Zelda than any other Zelda game out there. Its overworld is a silent beauty. Decaying ruins, little civilization, and a lot of wild animals. I did not mean it as a bad thing when I said that BotW builds atmosphere using sound effects instead of music. Unlike for example Dark Souls, which does the same thing, I would say that BotW really nailed this technique.
author: Eirian Odalis

text: +Eirian Odalis Interesting. If that's the case then that's a good thing. There's many perfect scores for BOTW so I'm definitely interested in buying it. I'm still in awe of Windwaker and how great that game was since I myself went into that with little expectations lol...was I wrong...

text: My playthrough is winding down a bit at 120 hours. There are a few sidequests and shrines left, and I already look at a lot of places of Hyrule and thinking "Man, I wish I could explore this for the first time again." That's how you know you're playing an incredible game. It's not perfect, I have a few problems with it, but it's one of the best games I've played in a long time, and I'm really excited to see what's next for the franchise.

author: GiantSandles

text:
I imagine BotW's OST was designed to be more ambient. Since you'll be travelling a lot in the overworld, they probably wanted to avoid the music from being repetitive and distract you from taking in the glorious environments surrounding you. The more standout tracks were given to all the towns (since you won't stay in them too long, they wrote the songs to be more impressive and therefore memorable, before leaving them), as well as the battles to increase the tension/drama of the action.

If they made a standout track like OoT's Hyrule Field and put it on repeat in BotW's overworld, it would probably get really old fast (despite how good it is.)
author: TheTJWorks

text: Yeah, it makes sense, it's just after previous games having some of the best video game soundtracks of all time, it's slightly underwhelming to have just a good soundtrack for this

text: It is a great soundtrack, it is just not as good to just listen too as the previous titles. I think the music is awesome in game though. It really brings out the atmosphere they were aiming for.
author: Eirian Odalis

text: I don't think it was the soundtrack itself that was bad, but the lack of one. There wasn't a lot of music in the game, but in the sparse areas that had music, they were fantastic. This track, Calamity Ganon battle, Rito Village, Gerudo City, Kakariko, the Divine Beast Battles, Blight battles, Sandworm battle, and Horse-Night theme are just a few themes that sounded amazing. It's a shame that the developers decided to go with a more ambient soundtrack then a full blown orchestral arrangement like previous games.
author: Sandeep Singh

text: I guess you just have poor and easily distracted taste. The subtly and delivery of all the music in Breath Of The Wild is moving and graceful more so than any 3 minute jingle you hear on repeat in other Zelda games.

text:
To be honest, I love Breath of the Wild's music. Sure, it's not as memorable as the previous titles but there is something special about that music that feels "Zelda-ish" with that atmosphere. Maybe it's because of this atmosphere that I still remember of the music. I feel an epic soundtrack would break that universe and I could be kinda annoyed by that.
But I understand what you are saying. There's so much memorable music in the saga that BotW's music sounds odd or unusual.
